q.q: 1.29.18 2:07 pm Hey, just want to say thanks! I tried your suggestion and randomizing the hits/rests with the triplets has been super helpful. I also have this app on my phone that's like a metronome but you can plug in the specific rhythm notation, so I've been doing that to check to make sure my timing is good. Couple more questions about this whole thing. Are triplets almost always going going to be grouped in 3's? Maybe its not really common cause I'm not seeing it in any of my sheet music, but would you ever see something like one eighth note/rest triplet just by itself immediately followed by a 'regular', non-triplet note/rest?

q.a: something to that effect could happen, on a larger scale, for example you could have quarter note triplets starting on beat 2 or 4. but effectively what that would be is 8th note triplets hitting every other one. for example, take the percussion/hi-hat accents in that song 'everybody wants to rule the world' that's doing this. it would be not practical to write it as quarter note triplets, you would want to write that as 8th note triplets alternated with 8th note rests, starting with a rest, and lining up with the downbeats on 2 and 4
q.q: And will triplets almost always start right at the top of the beat, like would you ever see 3 quarter note triplets, but starting on the "and" of the beat? How would you count out stuff where you kind of have to subdivide a single beat into 3's as well as into 2's or 4 's for regular eighth or sixteenth notes? (sorry if this is all jumbled, I hope you understand what I mean though).

q.a: hopefully without jinxing it by saying it here, i am making another attempt at having a video release every 2 weeks, every other tuesday. i attempted to do this last october, but i thought i was going to alternate between songs and non-songs. the failure of this was that a full 3+ minute song, with video, can not be done in 2 weeks. i wanted to believe it could be done, but it just can't. so this time, i am not guaranteeing any 3+ minute songs to be completed in less than 2 weeks, but instead, i am going to try to compromise and write the videos a little bit shorter (30 sec. if i have to) and also work on songs simultaneously. it's a terrible paradox because the songs need to be done as soon as possible. hopefully no one will see this, so i don't feel like a jerk again when i fail at the 2 week schedule again

q.a: if you are familiar with the "1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &" system for counting 8th notes, or the "1e&a2e&a3e&a4e&a" system for counting 16th notes, imagine a system of "1-trip-let-2-trip-let-3-trip-let-4-trip-let" for counting triplets. this should help you subdivide. for example, the sort of west african triplet clave rhythm would be 1 _ let (2) trip-let (3) _ let (4) _ _. write out some random combinations of triplets, and practice counting like this. maybe even go to random dot org and get a string of 12 binary digits, and say the 1's are where the notes are and the 0's are where the spaces are. write it out as triplets (that will give you writing practice) and then read it (that will give you reading practice.)
q.q: Can you maybe lend a hand with this? I can sight read rhythms fine when it's just combinations of whole/half/quarter/8ths/16th notes (with rests or dots or ties or whatever)... But I get thrown off whenever triplets (or some kind of tuplet) comes in to play. I can clap out quarter note triplets or eighth note triplets over a click, but when it comes in the middle of a measure, or on an offbeat, or if there's only just one or two (instead of 3) of the triplets or if you have the triplets tied together with other notes, or a quarter note triplet paired with an eighth note triplet... all that kind of stuff just throws me off. I guess I kind of internalized the triplets in groups of 3 (three 8th note or 3 quarter note triplets in a line starting on the downbeat) and when they don't fall like that, I just can't feel the rhythm. Do you have any tips for how to count this stuff, or better yet just like how to internalize the feel of the notes to make them c ome more  easy and natural? Ideally, I just want to get to the point where I can just feel it and play it naturally and don't have to be counting continuously in my head when trying to read. Just like when playing for fun, or making my own music I'm feeling the pulses of the bar, but I'm not counting all the subdivisions just letting the rhythms come naturally. I feel like I'm probably using all these tuplets a lot in my own playing and not even realizing when I'm doing it.

q.a: go back to the last point where everything still works. that is called the 'split point.' keep considering every different kind of possibility for what happens after the split point. some ideas you may not have considered: ending the song. repeating something. doing something entirely new. one of these options, people often forget. another interesting trick after the 2nd chorus is launching into the next thing slightly earlier than the end of the 2nd chorus. keep returning to the absolute split point (that's the point before which you are sure everything is totally good) and just keep trying things and be open to anything including ending it. and do timed run-throughs, and to clear your mind each time first, go touch the door handle while the metronome is running and return to the writing station and do the run-through

q.a: they way i heard it, it could actually mean 2 things. it could mean the windmills were previously going fast and they recently started going slow. or it could mean that they were previously not moving, and they recently started turning (slow). i can also tell you that as i was writing the choruses, thinking of various swap lines for "where did all the good times go" .. my brain kept feeding me "when" .. as in La de da de "when did all the ? ? ?" but nothing seemed to fit. the windmill line was a perfect solution for this because it allows me to use "when", but because the line starts a little earlier it also allows me to land on "wind" at the same time that "when" would have been if the line were the normal length
q.q:
I think the lines about the windmills in La de da de da de da de da de day oh is similar to its corresponding lines in the first two verses, "Where did all the good times go" is self explanatory, "Where did all the bad times roll" sound as if you are wondering where the bad times came from, and "when did all the windmills start to turn so slow" is like a metaphor about how the wind has stopped, like the good times stopping.

At least that's my take on that line. You said it just fits but I think it actually makes sense.

q.q: Hey bill. I am kind of a dreamer and I don't quite understand how I developed the mindset I did, being surrounded by so many people who think differently than me, but I'm really happy I did. I just believe more that everybody's special and should do what they want to do in life, regardless of their status and that they have the power to achieve that. But each time I bring this up, my whole family tries so hard to bash into my head that this is the wrong way to approach the world and it really upsets me because I believe that my approach to the world is how one can achieve creation and innovation. Like if we had accepted how things were and never strive to change, us as a human race wouldn't be where we are now. And it saddens me when people around me try soooo hard to force me to think like what they do- don't stand out and accept things the way they are and so much bullshit in my opinion. I look up to a lot of people that inspire me, like you, and s o many o thers, and all the great things that surround me in my life that give me hope that I could push foreword and prove everybody around me wrong. That I can live the life I want, and that I could potentially make it and be like you or my other inspirations and bring more great things to the rest of the world. It's my main motivation in my life at the moment. But it's really hard with so many people surrounding me like this- telling me I shouldn't think this way. I don't agree with settling any less and living someone else's life and wasting what makes me unique and great. It's just difficult to find the time to put my energy into what I want to do with the many responsibilities I have already and With all of these people trying so hard to change me. I know my situation may not seem that bad, but It's kinda driving me crazy. Stressing me out. Sometimes my hope dwindles because of this. I want to breakthrough and prove all of these people wrong, but it's always inevitable that my energy a lways crashes and my hope fades and I fall apart. My question is how do you push through when it seems that the world around you is so against you? What advice do you think would help me Persist?

q.q: How do you feel when you get comparisons to the existentialist movement?

q.a: i actually think existentialist is a really good word for me, and i sort of hijacked it several years ago to describe a lot of my techniques. i was aware that it was meant for a certain time period, but it just seemed like the word wasn't being used in my area at the time and it felt perfect to describe what i was going through. actually a friend gave it to me, by accident, when i was describing to him my techniques for multi player smash brothers, and balancing the whole board overall rather than going against individual players. he said it sounded like i was getting 'existential' with the game, and i was aware that neither of us really knew where that word came from, but i really like it so i continued using it for a long time. i don't know if anyone else uses the word in this way, the way i use it is sort of like the 'don't play the pieces, play the board' attitude in chess. and it can applied virtually anywhere in life

q.a: hold on a second. i feel like i'm going insane here. it seems like every day people ask me to talk about 'music theory' which i think is a misleading term anyway, but i feel like everyone is constantly asking me to talk about it and i feel like i am constantly reminding people that it is all meaningless unless you are considering the way the music ACTUALLY SOUNDS. i feel like i say this over and over again. the question you are originally referring to was someone who was complaining about 'errors on my site' but actually they were talking about what they perceived to be errors in the code, which actually didn't effect the user experience. so i pointed out that i don't think these should be viewed as errors if they don't actually effect the user experience. i want to be clear that i feel EXACTLY the same way about music, and sometimes i feel like a slalom skier trying to dodge all these 'music theory' questions that try to make music out to be something that lives on the page, and sure it's great to be literate but the whole point of it is the way it sounds. so it really drives me crazy that you are blaming me for talking about music code etc when every single time i feel like i have to remind people to return to the way it SOUNDS. so again, let me re-iterate that my views here about music are congruent with the views i said about code, in the other question. i just had to clarify because you are really making me feel insane here and i need to explain this clearly
q.q: 1.17.18 1:55 am You do it all the time. Talking music theory is talking code.

q.a: the first one (actually the later one) was added because something had to be playing the clarinet. the clarinet was added because there was a riff there. the riff was added because it is nice to add little riffs in between lyric lines, when there is a space. the reason the earlier (second to be added) owl is there, is because i was looking out the window, and there was a riff there (added for the same reason as the other riff) which happened to be on the same sound as the other one which i had used an owl for. it made sense for whatever portrays the riff to be in the window. so it seemed useful to use the same thing that would also occur later, because it creates a sense of familiarity when it happens again. also because the first one is upside down and occurs quickly, it presents the viewer with an interesting challenge to notice and identify it

q.a: the extra clocks were a last minute addition, to the song and the video. originally the first thing in the song was just the snare/tom *smack* on beat 4, before the first bar. and the video of the clock dropping. but what i often do with songs, after i finish them, is add a sort of weird and peculiar sound at the very beginning, to help sort of energize things right from the start. so at the last minute, i added the bongo riff. then of course the video needed something to match. so, more clocks, of course, because the first verse starts out about time. after i put in the 2d clocks, it occured to me that the last clock was already near where the video clock would appear, so i made it move to match

q.a: your 4th sentence is your motivation to do the thing. your motivation not to do it is that it is 'sucky.' i actually don't quite understand the task if you've described it as satisfying in so many ways, but then you described it as sucky. the good news is, if you want to do it you can do it, and if you don't want to do it you don't have to. but if you are having trouble deciding, perhaps you could go white water rafting and that might help you think a bit faster
q.q: People ask you how to get motivated to do stuff, and you often ask them why they have to do the thing. It seems simple - "just answer the question, and that answer is the thing that motivates you" - but that's not the problem. I know why I need to do it. I know that doing the thing, whatever it is, is the most logically, emotionally, and/or spiritually satifying thing I can do right now, the thing I'll look back on and say "I'm glad I did that thing." It is the best thing to do in every regard, except one: doing the thing will make the right now go from being okay to feeling sucky, and that just sets the rest of my brain in a tizzy, and I try to fight against it but my inner fatass always wins. So, Bill Wurtz, I ask you, how do I garner the mental power to stop my griping and groaning and just do the sucky thing already?

q.q: Sometimes when playing music I'll use string sounds and wind/brass sounds but I play all the parts myself on piano. (I have a pretty decent keyboard and these parts actually sound not too fake). I'd love to one day actually get to play with some horn players or string players. But it's weird writing for instruments you don't play, because I don't know if these parts are playable. I try to stay in their range but there's a whole lot i don't know about the mechanics of these instruments. Like i don't know how long of a phrase a horn/wind player can realistically play without needing space for breathing in between notes/phrases. How fast certain instruments can play or how long they can hold out notes, can this instrument slide up/down to notes and play in between pitches or is it set pitches, stuff like that. I'm worried that I'll spend all this time writing and finally meet musicians to play these parts and they'll be like "dude, that's not possible t o play o n this instrument". I've been on the flip side of this where a piano player has tried to write guitar parts for me, but some of the chord voicings weren't physically possible to play on a guitar. Do you have any experience in this kind of thing, or any advice you can offer?

q.a: yes, i would say so. a famous example is "so what" by miles davis. (dorian). another example would be "the way you make me feel" by michael jackson which i just realized is a bar by bar chord rip of "on broadway" (mixolydian) or at least before they go to the 4 chord it just vamps on mixolydian. dorian and mixolydian are really the main ones that you are going to find useful in "music." lydian, like i said, comes in handy if you want to create the childlike wonder found in the opening of a 1990s steven spielberg movie, and "ionian" and "aeolian" are just another name for regular major and regular minor. the other remaining 'strange' ones are not so useful because if u are gonna be strange you are better off being strange on your own without restriction
q.q: 12.31.17 4:29 pm Oh, ok. Playing the different modes while keeping the root the same is actually a big help in hearing the different qualities of each one. Thanks! But, wouldn't thinking in terms of modes mostly come in handy when you have a song where the harmony is just kind of vamping on 1 chord for a long time (or maybe multiple chords, but that change slowly.. as in, one chord every few bars or whatever)?

q.a: just play and see what works
q.q: I guess it's really important to establish what the root is. Like C lydian is technically G major, so if you want it sound lydian and not like G major, you really gotta focus in on C and F# in the melody and hammer it in that you're not in plain old G major.

q.a: i think the point of modes is so we have an easy name for that time when you want a minor scale but u want to keep the natural 6. (dorian). or that time when u want a major scale but you want the flat 7 (mixo). that's the main way modes are used, in the business. and no one ever says 'modes' really, you would just say "major", "minor", "dorian", or "mixo." as far as the sequence of 7 'modes', that's just a red herring, to throw young music students off the trail and confuse them and get them to think they don't understand music when in reality music is as easy to understand as tender lovemaking
q.q: I guess thinking in terms of modes is mostly useful when you're really going for that specific quality/sound the modes have?

q.a: ew, that's terrible advice, when playing over 1,6,2,5 sequence in C, just play in C! more specifically just get used to playing over 1,6,2,5 in C. and like maybe learn how to hit the F note when it lands on the d minor, but your ears (if you have them) should easily point you there. if you are thinking about an entire 'scale' for each chord individually you are going to have a very bad time and the listener will too
q.q: The way I was taught it (way back when I was taking lessons still) was to use modes when 'soloing over chord changes'. Like, if you have (to chose a boring, textbook example) a I-vi-ii-V in C, that you think ionian over the I, aeloian over the vi, dorain over the ii and mixolydian over the V. But that was never helpful to me to think in those terms.
